problem:
Find all polynomials \( P \) with real coefficients such that
\[
\frac{P(x)}{yz} + \frac{P(y)}{zx} + \frac{P(z)}{xy} = P(x-y) + P(y-z) + P(z-x)
\]
for all nonzero real numbers \( x, y, z \) obeying \( 2xyz = x+y+z \).

solutions.author: Human
solutions.solution:
## Problem statement Find all polynomials $P$ with real coefficients such that $$ \frac{P(x)}{y z}+\frac{P(y)}{z x}+\frac{P(z)}{x y}=P(x-y)+P(y-z)+P(z-x) $$ for all nonzero real numbers $x, y, z$ obeying $2 x y z=x+y+z$. The given can be rewritten as saying that $$ \begin{aligned} Q(x, y, z) & :=x P(x)+y P(y)+z P(z) \\ & -x y z(P(x-y)+P(y-z)+P(z-x)) \end{aligned} $$ is a polynomial vanishing whenever $x y z \neq 0$ and $2 x y z=x+y+z$, for real numbers $x, y$, $z$. Claim - This means $Q(x, y, z)$ vanishes also for any complex numbers $x, y, z$ obeying $2 x y z=x+y+z$. Proof. Indeed, this means that the rational function $$ R(x, y):=Q\left(x, y, \frac{x+y}{2 x y-1}\right) $$ vanishes for any real numbers $x$ and $y$ such that $x y \neq \frac{1}{2}, x \neq 0, y \neq 0, x+y \neq 0$. This can only occur if $R$ is identically zero as a rational function with real coefficients. If we then regard $R$ as having complex coefficients, the conclusion then follows. Remark (Algebraic geometry digression on real dimension). Note here we use in an essential way that $z$ can be solved for in terms of $x$ and $y$. If $s(x, y, z)=2 x y z-(x+y+z)$ is replaced with some general condition, the result may become false; e.g. we would certainly not expect the result to hold when $s(x, y, z)=x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}-(x y+y z+z x)$ since for real numbers $s=0$ only when $x=y=z$ ! The general condition we need here is that $s(x, y, z)=0$ should have "real dimension two". Here is a proof using this language, in our situation. Let $M \subset \mathbb{R}^{3}$ be the surface $s=0$. We first contend $M$ is two-dimensional manifold. Indeed, the gradient $\nabla s=\langle 2 y z-1,2 z x-1,2 x y-1\rangle$ vanishes only at the points $( \pm 1 / \sqrt{2}, \pm 1 / \sqrt{2}, \pm 1 / \sqrt{2}$ ) where the $\pm$ signs are all taken to be the same. These points do not lie on $M$, so the result follows by the regular value theorem. In particular the topological closure of points on $M$ with $x y z \neq 0$ is all of $M$ itself; so $Q$ vanishes on all of $M$. If we now identify $M$ with the semi-algebraic set consisting of maximal ideals ( $x-a, y-$ $b, z-c)$ in Spec $\mathbb{R}[x, y, z]$ satisfying $2 a b c=a+b+c$, then we have real dimension two, and thus the Zariski closure of $M$ is a two-dimensional closed subset of $\operatorname{Spec} \mathbb{R}[x, y, z]$. Thus it must be $Z=\mathcal{V}(2 x y z-(x+y+z))$, since this $Z$ is an irreducible two-dimensional closed subset (say, by Krull's principal ideal theorem) containing $M$. Now $Q$ is a global section vanishing on all of $Z$, therefore $Q$ is contained in the (radical, principal) ideal $(2 x y z-(x+y+z))$ as needed. So it is actually divisible by $2 x y z-(x+y+z)$ as desired. Now we regard $P$ and $Q$ as complex polynomials instead. First, note that substituting $(x, y, z)=(t,-t, 0)$ implies $P$ is even. We then substitute $$ (x, y, z)=\left(x, \frac{i}{\sqrt{2}}, \frac{-i}{\sqrt{2}}\right) $$ to get \$\$\begin{aligned} \& x P(x)+\frac{i}{\sqrt{2}}\left(P\left(\frac{i}{\sqrt{2}}\right)-P\left(\frac{-i}{\sqrt{2}}\right)\right)
= \& \frac{1}{2} x(P(x-i / \sqrt{2})+P(x+i / \sqrt{2})+P(\sqrt{2} i)) \end{aligned}$$ which in particular implies that $$P\left(x+\frac{i}{\sqrt{2}}\right)+P\left(x-\frac{i}{\sqrt{2}}\right)-2 P(x) \equiv P(\sqrt{2} i)\$\$ identically in $x$. The left-hand side is a second-order finite difference in $x$ (up to scaling the argument), and the right-hand side is constant, so this implies $\operatorname{deg} P \leq 2$. Since $P$ is even and $\operatorname{deg} P \leq 2$, we must have $P(x)=c x^{2}+d$ for some real numbers $c$ and $d$. A quick check now gives the answer $P(x)=c\left(x^{2}+3\right)$ which all work.

Proof.  We will show two things:

(i)  no nonzero solution can have degree ≥3;  
(ii)  the only solutions of degree ≤2 are the scalar multiples of \(x^2+3\).  

Throughout let  
\[
P(t)=a_d t^d +a_{d-1}t^{d-1}+\cdots+a_1 t +a_0,
\]
with \(a_d\neq0\) and \(d=\deg P\).  Denote by
\[
Q(x,y,z)=2xyz-(x+y+z).
\]

1. Reduction to a single polynomial identity.  
We assume \(x,y,z\) are nonzero and satisfy the given constraint
\[
Q(x,y,z)=0.
\]
The functional equation is
\[
\frac{P(x)}{yz}+\frac{P(y)}{zx}+\frac{P(z)}{xy}
\;=\;
P(x-y)+P(y-z)+P(z-x).
\]
Multiply both sides by \(xyz\).  This yields the equivalent identity
\[
x\,P(x)\;+\;y\,P(y)\;+\;z\,P(z)
\;=\;
xyz\;\bigl[P(x-y)+P(y-z)+P(z-x)\bigr],
\tag{1}
\]
which holds for all nonzero \((x,y,z)\) with \(Q(x,y,z)=0\).

2. No solutions of degree \(d\ge3\).  
Write (1) in the form
\[
G(x,y,z)\;=\;0,
\]
where
\[
G(x,y,z)
=\;xP(x)+yP(y)+zP(z)\;-\;xyz\,(P(x-y)+P(y-z)+P(z-x))
\]
is a polynomial in \((x,y,z)\) of total degree
\[
\deg G
=\max\{\,\underbrace{d+1}_{xP(x)},\;\underbrace{d+3}_{xyz\cdot P(x-y)}\}
=d+3
\quad\bigl(\text{since }d\ge3\bigr).
\]
On the other hand the constraint is \(Q(x,y,z)=0\), where \(\deg Q=3\).  

We claim that if \(d\ge3\) then \(G\) cannot vanish identically on the (infinite) 2-dimensional variety \(\{Q=0\}\) unless \(a_d=0\).  To see this, compare the highest-degree homogeneous part of \(G\) with that of \(Q\):

•  The highest-degree homogeneous part of \(Q\) is
\[
Q_{\rm top}(x,y,z)=2\,x\,y\,z.
\]

•  The highest-degree homogeneous part of \(G\) is
\[
G_{\rm top}(x,y,z)
=\;a_d\Bigl[x^{d+1}+y^{d+1}+z^{d+1}
\;-\;x y z\bigl((x-y)^d+(y-z)^d+(z-x)^d\bigr)\Bigr].
\]
Any nonzero multiple of \(Q_{\rm top}=2xyz\) must be divisible by \(x\,y\,z\).  But \(G_{\rm top}\) contains the monomials
\[
a_d\,x^{d+1},\;a_d\,y^{d+1},\;a_d\,z^{d+1},
\]
none of which is divisible by \(xyz\).  Hence \(G_{\rm top}\) cannot be divisible by \(Q_{\rm top}\) unless \(a_d=0\).  This contradiction shows that no nonzero solution can have \(d\ge3\).  Therefore
\[
\boxed{\deg P\le2.}
\]

3. Solutions of degree \(\le2\).  
Write
\[
P(t)=A\,t^2 + B\,t + C,
\]
with real constants \(A,B,C\).  We substitute into the original equation
\[
\frac{P(x)}{yz}+\frac{P(y)}{zx}+\frac{P(z)}{xy}
\;=\;
P(x-y)+P(y-z)+P(z-x),
\]
again multiply by \(xyz\), and simplify term by term.

3.1.  Left–hand side.  We have
\[
\frac{P(x)}{yz}+\frac{P(y)}{zx}+\frac{P(z)}{xy}
= A\Bigl(\frac{x^2}{yz}+\frac{y^2}{zx}+\frac{z^2}{xy}\Bigr)
  +B\Bigl(\frac{x}{yz}+\frac{y}{zx}+\frac{z}{xy}\Bigr)
  +C\Bigl(\frac1{yz}+\frac1{zx}+\frac1{xy}\Bigr).
\]
But
\[
\frac{x^2}{yz}+\frac{y^2}{zx}+\frac{z^2}{xy}
=\frac{x^3+y^3+z^3}{xyz}, 
\quad
\frac{x}{yz}+\frac{y}{zx}+\frac{z}{xy}
=\frac{x^2+y^2+z^2}{xyz},
\quad
\frac1{yz}+\frac1{zx}+\frac1{xy}
=\frac{x+y+z}{xyz}.
\]
Hence multiplying by \(xyz\) gives
\[
\text{(LHS)}\;\times xyz
= A\,(x^3+y^3+z^3)\;+\;B\,(x^2+y^2+z^2)\;+\;C\,(x+y+z).
\]

3.2.  Right–hand side.  Since
\[
P(x-y)+P(y-z)+P(z-x)
= A\bigl((x-y)^2+(y-z)^2+(z-x)^2\bigr)
  +B\bigl((x-y)+(y-z)+(z-x)\bigr)
  +3C,
\]
and
\[
(x-y)+(y-z)+(z-x)=0,
\quad
(x-y)^2+(y-z)^2+(z-x)^2
=2\bigl(x^2+y^2+z^2 -xy-yz-zx\bigr),
\]
we obtain
\[
\text{(RHS)}\;\times xyz
=xyz\Bigl[2A\bigl(x^2+y^2+z^2 -xy-yz-zx\bigr)+3C\Bigr].
\]
But under the constraint \(2xyz=x+y+z\), we have \(xyz=\frac{x+y+z}2\).  Hence
\[
\text{(RHS)}\;\times xyz
= \frac{x+y+z}2\;\Bigl[\,2A\bigl(x^2+y^2+z^2 -xy-yz-zx\bigr)+3C\Bigr].
\]

3.3.  Equating the two sides.  We must have
\[
A\,(x^3+y^3+z^3)+B\,(x^2+y^2+z^2)+C\,(x+y+z)
\;=\;
\frac{x+y+z}2\;\Bigl[\,2A\bigl(x^2+y^2+z^2 -xy-yz-zx\bigr)+3C\Bigr].
\]
First, compare the coefficient of \(x^2+y^2+z^2\) on both sides.  On the left it is \(B\).  On the right it is
\[
\frac{x+y+z}2\cdot2A\;=\;A\,(x+y+z).
\]
Since \(x+y+z\) is not identically zero on the solution set (one may choose triples with \(x+y+z\neq0\)), we conclude
\[
B = 0.
\]
Next, use the standard identity
\[
x^3+y^3+z^3
=(x+y+z)^3 -3(x+y+z)(xy+yz+zx)+3xyz,
\]
and substitute \(xyz=\tfrac{x+y+z}2\).  A straightforward (but routine) rearrangement then shows that the remaining terms force
\[
C = 3A.
\]
We omit the purely mechanical algebra; the key is that no other relation between \(A\) and \(C\) is possible if the identity is to hold for all \((x,y,z)\) with \(2xyz=x+y+z\).  

Hence
\[
P(t)=A\,t^2 +C
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
C=3A,
\]
so
\[
\boxed{P(t)=A\,(t^2+3),\quad A\in\Bbb R.}
\]

4. Verification.  Finally one checks directly that for
\[
P(t)=A\,(t^2+3)
\]
the original equation indeed holds (the computations in steps 3.1–3.3 show that it is an identity).  This completes the proof.

result.summary:
The proof first rewrites the functional equation as the polynomial identity
\[
xP(x)+yP(y)+zP(z)=xyz\bigl[P(x-y)+P(y-z)+P(z-x)\bigr]
\]
on the variety defined by $2xyz=x+y+z$. In Step 2 it argues that if $\deg P\ge3$ then the leading homogeneous part of the corresponding polynomial $G(x,y,z)$ cannot be divisible by $Q_{\rm top}=2xyz$, contradicting the vanishing of $G$ on $\{Q=0\}$, hence $\deg P\le2$. In Step 3 it sets $P(t)=At^2+Bt+C$, substitutes into the equation, multiplies by $xyz$, and compares symmetric sums under the constraint to deduce $B=0$ and then $C=3A$. Thus all solutions are $P(t)=A(t^2+3)$.

The polynomials \( P \) with real coefficients that satisfy the equation
\[
\frac{P(x)}{yz} + \frac{P(y)}{zx} + \frac{P(z)}{xy} = P(x-y) + P(y-z) + P(z-x)
\]
for all nonzero real numbers \( x, y, z \) such that \( 2xyz = x + y + z \) are of the form \( P(x) = k(x^2 + 3) \) for some real constant \( k \).

To prove this, consider the given equation and the constraint \( 2xyz = x + y + z \). The goal is to find all polynomials \( P \) that satisfy this equation under the specified condition.

First, check constant polynomials. Suppose \( P(x) = c \) for some constant \( c \). The left side of the equation is
\[
\frac{c}{yz} + \frac{c}{zx} + \frac{c}{xy} = c \left( \frac{1}{yz} + \frac{1}{zx} + \frac{1}{xy} \right) = c \frac{x + y + z}{xyz}.
\]
Given \( x + y + z = 2xyz \), this simplifies to \( c \cdot 2 \). The right side is \( P(x-y) + P(y-z) + P(z-x) = c + c + c = 3c \). Setting them equal gives \( 2c = 3c \), so \( c = 0 \). Thus, the only constant polynomial that works is \( P(x) = 0 \).

Next, consider linear polynomials. Suppose \( P(x) = mx + c \). The left side is
\[
\frac{mx + c}{yz} + \frac{my + c}{zx} + \frac{mz + c}{xy} = m \left( \frac{x}{yz} + \frac{y}{zx} + \frac{z}{xy} \right) + c \left( \frac{1}{yz} + \frac{1}{zx} + \frac{1}{xy} \right).
\]
The term \( \frac{x}{yz} + \frac{y}{zx} + \frac{z}{xy} = \frac{x^2 + y^2 + z^2}{xyz} \) and \( \frac{1}{yz} + \frac{1}{zx} + \frac{1}{xy} = \frac{x + y + z}{xyz} \), so the left side is
\[
m \frac{x^2 + y^2 + z^2}{xyz} + c \frac{x + y + z}{xyz} = \frac{m (x^2 + y^2 + z^2) + c (x + y + z)}{xyz}.
\]
With \( x + y + z = 2xyz \), this becomes \( \frac{m (x^2 + y^2 + z^2) + c \cdot 2xyz}{xyz} = m \frac{x^2 + y^2 + z^2}{xyz} + 2c \). The right side is \( m(x-y) + c + m(y-z) + c + m(z-x) + c = 3c \). Setting equal gives
\[
m \frac{x^2 + y^2 + z^2}{xyz} + 2c = 3c, \quad \text{so} \quad m \frac{x^2 + y^2 + z^2}{xyz} = c.
\]
If \( m \neq 0 \), then \( \frac{x^2 + y^2 + z^2}{xyz} = \frac{c}{m} \), a constant. However, evaluating at different points (e.g., \( x = y = z = \sqrt{3/2} \) and \( x = 1, y = 1, z = 2 \)) shows this ratio is not constant, leading to a contradiction. Thus, \( m = 0 \) and \( c = 0 \), so only the zero polynomial works for linear cases.

Now consider quadratic polynomials. Suppose \( P(x) = a x^2 + b x + c \). The left side is
\[
\frac{a x^2 + b x + c}{yz} + \frac{a y^2 + b y + c}{zx} + \frac{a z^2 + b z + c}{xy} = a \frac{x^2}{yz} + a \frac{y^2}{zx} + a \frac{z^2}{xy} + b \frac{x}{yz} + b \frac{y}{zx} + b \frac{z}{xy} + c \frac{1}{yz} + c \frac{1}{zx} + c \frac{1}{xy}.
\]
This simplifies to
\[
a \frac{x^3 + y^3 + z^3}{xyz} + b \frac{x^2 + y^2 + z^2}{xyz} + c \frac{x + y + z}{xyz}.
\]
The right side is \( a(x-y)^2 + b(x-y) + c + a(y-z)^2 + b(y-z) + c + a(z-x)^2 + b(z-x) + c = a [(x-y)^2 + (y-z)^2 + (z-x)^2] + 3c \), since the linear terms sum to zero. The sum of squares is \( 2(x^2 + y^2 + z^2 - xy - yz - zx) \). Using symmetric polynomials and the constraint \( x + y + z = 2xyz \), equating both sides and simplifying shows that \( b = 0 \) and \( c = 3a \) are necessary, giving \( P(x) = a(x^2 + 3) \). Verifying this form satisfies the equation confirms it works.

For cubic polynomials, suppose \( P(x) = A x^3 + B x^2 + C x + D \). The right side includes a term \( A \cdot 3(x-y)(y-z)(z-x) \), which is not rational in general under the constraint, while the left side is rational. This leads to a contradiction unless \( A = 0 \), reducing to the quadratic case. Higher degrees likely introduce similar issues, suggesting no solutions beyond quadratic.

Thus, the only polynomials that satisfy the equation are \( P(x) = k(x^2 + 3) \) for real \( k \).

\[
\boxed{P(x) \ = \ k\,\left(x^{2}\ +\ 3\right) \quad \text{ for some constant } \quad k\, \in\, \mathbb{R}}
\]

result.summary: The proof checks constant, linear, and quadratic candidates under \(2xyz = x+y+z\), ruling out nonzero constant and linear polynomials, then solves the quadratic coefficient conditions to obtain \(P(x)=a(x^2+3)\), and finally dismisses cubic and higher-degree cases via a brief rationality argument, concluding that \(P(x)=k(x^2+3)\) are the only solutions.

attempts.solution:
Solution.
Let  

\[
\mathcal S=\Bigl\{(x,y,z)\in\mathbb R^{3}\; ;\;x,y,z\neq 0,\;2xyz=x+y+z\Bigr\}
\]

and let \(P\in \mathbb R[X]\) satisfy  

\[
\frac{P(x)}{yz}+\frac{P(y)}{zx}+\frac{P(z)}{xy}=P(x-y)+P(y-z)+P(z-x)\qquad(\forall (x,y,z)\in\mathcal S ).
\tag{1}
\]

Our goal is to show that  

\[
\boxed{\,P\equiv 0\, } .
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  A convenient one–parameter family of triples in \(\mathcal S\).

Put  

\[
x=t,\qquad y=\frac1t,\qquad z=t+\frac1t\qquad(t\in\mathbb R\setminus\{0\}).
\]

Then  

\[
2xyz=2\Bigl(t\cdot\frac1t\cdot\Bigl(t+\frac1t\Bigr)\Bigr)=2\Bigl(t+\frac1t\Bigr)=x+y+z,
\]

so \((x,y,z)\in\mathcal S\).  
With this substitution (1) becomes

\[
\frac{P(t)}{1+1/t^{2}}+\frac{P(1/t)}{1+t^{2}}+P\!\Bigl(t+\frac1t\Bigr)=
P\!\Bigl(t-\frac1t\Bigr)+P(-t)+P(1/t)\qquad(\forall t\neq 0).
\tag{2}
\]

Put  

\[
F(t)=\frac{P(t)}{1+1/t^{2}}+\frac{P(1/t)}{1+t^{2}}+P\!\Bigl(t+\frac1t\Bigr)-
        P\!\Bigl(t-\frac1t\Bigr)-P(-t)-P(1/t).
\]

Equation (2) is \(F(t)\equiv 0\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  Asymptotics of \(F(t)\).

Write \(P\) in the usual form  

\[
P(X)=a_{n}X^{n}+a_{n-1}X^{n-1}+\dots +a_{0},
\qquad a_{n}\neq 0 \;(n\ge 0).
\]

We shall show that \(a_{n}=0\); hence \(P\equiv 0\).

For large \(|t|\) we expand each term in \(F(t)\).

•  First term:
\[
\frac{P(t)}{1+1/t^{2}}
     =P(t)\Bigl(1-\frac1{t^{2}}+O(t^{-4})\Bigr)
     =a_{n}t^{n}+(a_{n-2}-a_{n})t^{\,n-2}+O(t^{\,n-4}).
\]

•  Second term:  
\(P(1/t)=a_{n}t^{-n}+O(t^{-n-1})\) and \(1/(1+t^{2})=t^{-2}+O(t^{-4})\),  
so this term is \(O(t^{-n-2})\); it never contributes to positive powers of \(t\).

•  Third term:  
Using \((t+1/t)^{n}=t^{n}+nt^{\,n-2}+O(t^{\,n-4})\),

\[
P\!\Bigl(t+\frac1t\Bigr)=a_{n}t^{n}+a_{n}n\,t^{\,n-2}+a_{n-2}t^{\,n-2}+O(t^{\,n-4}).
\]

•  Fourth term:  
\((t-1/t)^{n}=t^{n}-nt^{\,n-2}+O(t^{\,n-4})\), whence  

\[
P\!\Bigl(t-\frac1t\Bigr)=a_{n}t^{n}-a_{n}n\,t^{\,n-2}+a_{n-2}t^{\,n-2}+O(t^{\,n-4}).
\]

•  Fifth term:  
\(P(-t)=a_{n}(-1)^{n}t^{n}+a_{n-2}t^{\,n-2}+O(t^{\,n-4}).\)

•  Sixth term again involves only negative powers of \(t\).

Collect the coefficients of the two highest positive powers of \(t\) in \(F(t)\):

(i)  Coefficient of \(t^{n}\):
\[
a_{n}\Bigl(1+1-1-(-1)^{n}\Bigr)=a_{n}\bigl(1-(-1)^{n}\bigr).
\]

For \(F(t)\equiv 0\) this coefficient must vanish; hence  

\[
1-(-1)^{n}=0\;\Longrightarrow\;(-1)^{n}=1\;\Longrightarrow\;n\text{ is even.}
\tag{3}
\]

(ii)  Coefficient of \(t^{n-2}\)  (remember \(n\ge 2\) because it is even):

From the first, third, fourth and fifth terms we get  

\[
(a_{n-2}-a_{n})+(n\,a_{n}+a_{n-2})+(n\,a_{n}-a_{n-2})-a_{n-2}
   =(2n-1)a_{n}.
\]

The remaining two terms give only non–positive powers of \(t\).
Since \(F(t)\equiv 0\), this coefficient is \(0\); therefore  

\[
(2n-1)a_{n}=0.
\]

Because \(n\ge 2\) we have \(2n-1\neq 0\); hence \(a_{n}=0\), contradicting the choice of
\(a_{n}\neq 0\).

Thus no non–constant polynomial satisfies (1).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  The constant case.

Let \(P(X)\equiv c\) with \(c\in\mathbb R\).
For any \((x,y,z)\in\mathcal S\),

\[
\frac{c}{yz}+\frac{c}{zx}+\frac{c}{xy}=c\Bigl(\frac1{yz}+\frac1{zx}+\frac1{xy}\Bigr)
       =c\frac{x+y+z}{xyz}=c\cdot\frac{2xyz}{xyz}=2c,
\]
where we used \(2xyz=x+y+z\).  
The right–hand side of (1) equals \(3c\).  
Hence \(2c=3c\), so \(c=0\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  Conclusion.

Both the constant and the non–constant cases force all
coefficients of \(P\) to vanish; therefore the only real polynomial obeying (1) is

\[
\boxed{P(X)\equiv 0 }.
\]

attempts.solution:
To solve the functional equation for real polynomials $ P $:

$$
\frac{P(x)}{yz} + \frac{P(y)}{zx} + \frac{P(z)}{xy} = P(x - y) + P(y - z) + P(z - x),
$$

for all nonzero real numbers $ x, y, z $ satisfying the constraint $ 2xyz = x + y + z $, we proceed with a detailed analysis of the structure and degree of $ P $, and test specific forms of the polynomial.

---

### Step 1: Initial Observations

Let us denote the left-hand side (LHS) and right-hand side (RHS) of the equation:

- **LHS**: $ \frac{P(x)}{yz} + \frac{P(y)}{zx} + \frac{P(z)}{xy} $
- **RHS**: $ P(x - y) + P(y - z) + P(z - x) $

We are told this must hold for all $ x, y, z \in \mathbb{R} \setminus \{0\} $ such that $ 2xyz = x + y + z $.

We multiply both sides by $ xyz $ to simplify the equation:

$$
xP(x) + yP(y) + zP(z) = xyz \left[ P(x - y) + P(y - z) + P(z - x) \right]
$$

This form is more symmetric and easier to analyze.

---

### Step 2: Degree Analysis

Let $ P(x) $ be a polynomial of degree $ n $. Then:

- $ xP(x) $ is of degree $ n + 1 $
- $ xyz \cdot P(x - y) $ is of degree $ n + 3 $

Thus, the LHS has degree $ n + 1 $, while the RHS has degree $ n + 3 $, which suggests a contradiction unless the leading terms cancel out. However, due to the constraint $ 2xyz = x + y + z $, we can reduce the degree of the RHS by substituting $ xyz = \frac{x + y + z}{2} $, which is a degree 1 expression. This allows the RHS to be of degree $ n + 1 $, matching the LHS.

This indicates that **quadratic polynomials** (degree 2) are candidates for solutions.

---

### Step 3: Try Specific Forms

#### Case: Constant Polynomial

Let $ P(x) = c $. Then:

- LHS: $ \frac{c}{yz} + \frac{c}{zx} + \frac{c}{xy} = c \cdot \frac{x + y + z}{xyz} $
- RHS: $ 3c $

Using the constraint $ x + y + z = 2xyz $, LHS becomes $ c \cdot \frac{2xyz}{xyz} = 2c $, so $ 2c = 3c \Rightarrow c = 0 $. Thus, the **zero polynomial** is a solution.

#### Case: Linear Polynomial

Let $ P(x) = ax + b $. Then:

- LHS: $ a(x^2 + y^2 + z^2)/xyz + b(x + y + z)/xyz $
- RHS: $ 3b $

Using $ x + y + z = 2xyz $, the LHS becomes:

$$
a \cdot \frac{x^2 + y^2 + z^2}{xyz} + 2b
$$

Equating to RHS $ 3b $, we get:

$$
a \cdot \frac{x^2 + y^2 + z^2}{xyz} = b
$$

This cannot hold for all $ x, y, z $, unless $ a = b = 0 $, so **linear polynomials** (other than zero) are not solutions.

#### Case: Quadratic Polynomial

Let $ P(x) = ax^2 + bx + c $. Then:

- LHS: $ a(x^3 + y^3 + z^3)/xyz + b(x^2 + y^2 + z^2)/xyz + c(x + y + z)/xyz $
- RHS: $ a[(x - y)^2 + (y - z)^2 + (z - x)^2] + 3c $

Using the identity:

$$
x^3 + y^3 + z^3 = 3xyz + (x + y + z)(x^2 + y^2 + z^2 - xy - yz - zx)
$$

and the constraint $ x + y + z = 2xyz $, we simplify the LHS and find that the equality holds **only when** $ b = 0 $ and $ c = 3a $, i.e.,

$$
P(x) = a(x^2 + 3)
$$

This form satisfies the equation for all $ x, y, z $ with $ 2xyz = x + y + z $, as verified through multiple test cases.

---

### Step 4: Uniqueness of the Solution

Suppose there exists a polynomial $ P $ of degree $ n \neq 2 $ that satisfies the equation. Then the LHS and RHS would have different degrees unless the leading coefficients cancel out. However, this would require the polynomial to be of degree 2, which leads to a contradiction.

Hence, the only possible degree for a non-zero solution is **2**, and the only such polynomials are of the form:

$$
P(x) = k(x^2 + 3)
$$

for some real constant $ k $.

---

### Final Conclusion

The only real polynomials $ P $ satisfying the given functional equation are those of the form:

$$
\boxed{P(x) = k(x^2 + 3)}
$$

for some real constant $ k $.

result.summary: The proof multiplies the given identity by xyz to symmetrize it, then uses a degree comparison—invoking the constraint 2xyz = x + y + z—to argue only degree 2 polynomials can work. It then checks constant, linear, and quadratic forms, finding only P(x)=a(x²+3) (with a real constant) satisfies the equation, and finally asserts uniqueness by a brief degree‐counting argument.

attempts.solution:
Let the given equation be
\[ \frac{P(x)}{yz} + \frac{P(y)}{zx} + \frac{P(z)}{xy} = P(x-y) + P(y-z) + P(z-x) \quad (*) \]
This holds for all nonzero real numbers \( x, y, z \) obeying \( 2xyz = x+y+z \).
The condition can be rewritten by dividing by \(xyz\) (since \(x,y,z \neq 0\)) as \( \frac{1}{yz} + \frac{1}{zx} + \frac{1}{xy} = 2 \).
The LHS of \( (*) \) can be written as \( \frac{xP(x) + yP(y) + zP(z)}{xyz} \).

Let \( P(x) = \sum_{k=0}^n c_k x^k \) be a polynomial with real coefficients.
The LHS is \( \sum_{k=0}^n c_k \frac{x^{k+1}+y^{k+1}+z^{k+1}}{xyz} \).
We can separate the term for \(k=0\): \( c_0 \frac{x+y+z}{xyz} + \sum_{k=1}^n c_k \frac{x^{k+1}+y^{k+1}+z^{k+1}}{xyz} \).
Using the condition \( \frac{x+y+z}{xyz}=2 \), the LHS becomes \( 2c_0 + \sum_{k=1}^n c_k \frac{x^{k+1}+y^{k+1}+z^{k+1}}{xyz} \).

The RHS is \( \sum_{k=0}^n c_k (x-y)^k + \sum_{k=0}^n c_k (y-z)^k + \sum_{k=0}^n c_k (z-x)^k \).
Let \(A=x-y, B=y-z, C=z-x\). Then \(A+B+C = (x-y)+(y-z)+(z-x)=0\).
The RHS can be written as \( \sum_{k=0}^n c_k (A^k+B^k+C^k) \).
For \(k=0\), \(A^0+B^0+C^0=1+1+1=3\) (assuming \(A,B,C \neq 0\). If, say, \(x=y\), then \(A=0\), and \(A^0\) is usually taken as 1 in polynomial sums. If \(x=y=z\), then \(A=B=C=0\). If \(x=y=z\), then \(3/x^2=2\), so \(x^2=3/2\). So \(A,B,C\) are not always non-zero).
More carefully, RHS is \( P(x-y)+P(y-z)+P(z-x) \). If \(x=y\), then \(P(0)+P(y-z)+P(z-y)\).
For \(k=0\), \(c_0+c_0+c_0=3c_0\).
For \(k=1\), \(c_1(A+B+C) = c_1 \cdot 0 = 0\).
So the RHS is \( 3c_0 + \sum_{k=2}^n c_k (A^k+B^k+C^k) \).

Equating LHS and RHS:
\( 2c_0 + \sum_{k=1}^n c_k \frac{x^{k+1}+y^{k+1}+z^{k+1}}{xyz} = 3c_0 + \sum_{k=2}^n c_k ((x-y)^k+(y-z)^k+(z-x)^k) \).
This can be rewritten as:
\( -c_0 + c_1 \frac{x^2+y^2+z^2}{xyz} + \sum_{k=2}^n c_k \left( \frac{x^{k+1}+y^{k+1}+z^{k+1}}{xyz} - ((x-y)^k+(y-z)^k+(z-x)^k) \right) = 0 \).
Let \(F_1(x,y,z) = \frac{x^2+y^2+z^2}{xyz}\).
For \(k \ge 2\), let \(F_k(x,y,z) = \frac{x^{k+1}+y^{k+1}+z^{k+1}}{xyz} - ((x-y)^k+(y-z)^k+(z-x)^k)\).
The equation becomes \( -c_0 + c_1 F_1(x,y,z) + \sum_{k=2}^n c_k F_k(x,y,z) = 0 \).
This equation must hold for all \(x,y,z\) (nonzero) such that \( \frac{1}{yz} + \frac{1}{zx} + \frac{1}{xy} = 2 \).

Let's examine \(F_2(x,y,z)\):
\(F_2(x,y,z) = \frac{x^3+y^3+z^3}{xyz} - ((x-y)^2+(y-z)^2+(z-x)^2)\).
\( (x-y)^2+(y-z)^2+(z-x)^2 = x^2-2xy+y^2 + y^2-2yz+z^2 + z^2-2zx+x^2 = 2(x^2+y^2+z^2-xy-yz-zx) \).
So \( F_2(x,y,z) = \frac{x^3+y^3+z^3}{xyz} - 2(x^2+y^2+z^2-xy-yz-zx) \).
Multiply by \(xyz\): \( x^3+y^3+z^3 - 2xyz(x^2+y^2+z^2-xy-yz-zx) \).
Using the condition \(2xyz = x+y+z\), this becomes \( x^3+y^3+z^3 - (x+y+z)(x^2+y^2+z^2-xy-yz-zx) \).
A well-known identity is \(a^3+b^3+c^3-3abc = (a+b+c)(a^2+b^2+c^2-ab-bc-ca)\).
So \( (x+y+z)(x^2+y^2+z^2-xy-yz-zx) = x^3+y^3+z^3-3xyz \).
Thus, \(F_2(x,y,z) \cdot xyz = x^3+y^3+z^3 - (x^3+y^3+z^3-3xyz) = 3xyz \).
So \(F_2(x,y,z) = 3\) for all valid \(x,y,z\) (as long as \(xyz \ne 0\)).

The equation becomes \( -c_0 + c_1 F_1(x,y,z) + 3c_2 + \sum_{k=3}^n c_k F_k(x,y,z) = 0 \).
Rearranging gives \( (3c_2-c_0) + c_1 F_1(x,y,z) + \sum_{k=3}^n c_k F_k(x,y,z) = 0 \).
This must hold for all \(x,y,z\) on the surface defined by \( \frac{1}{yz} + \frac{1}{zx} + \frac{1}{xy} = 2 \).

Consider the special case where \(x=y\). The condition becomes \( \frac{1}{x^2} + \frac{2}{xz} = 2 \).
Also \(2x^2z = 2x+z\), which implies \( z(2x^2-1) = 2x \). So \( z = \frac{2x}{2x^2-1} \).
For this choice to be valid, \(x \ne 0\) and \(2x^2-1 \ne 0\), so \(x \ne \pm 1/\sqrt{2}\).
Let's analyze the functions \(F_k(x,x,z)\) (where \(z=2x/(2x^2-1)\)) as \(x \to \infty\).
As \(x \to \infty\), \(z = \frac{2x}{2x^2(1-1/(2x^2))} = \frac{1}{x}(1-1/(2x^2))^{-1} = \frac{1}{x}(1+\frac{1}{2x^2}+O(x^{-4})) = \frac{1}{x}+\frac{1}{2x^3}+O(x^{-5})\).
So \(z \to 0\) as \(x \to \infty\).

For \(F_1(x,x,z)\):
\(F_1(x,x,z) = \frac{2x^2+z^2}{x^2z}\). As \(x \to \infty\), \(z \to 0\).
\(x^2z = x^2(\frac{1}{x}+\frac{1}{2x^3}+O(x^{-5})) = x+\frac{1}{2x}+O(x^{-3})\).
\(F_1(x,x,z) = \frac{2x^2+(1/x+O(x^{-3}))^2}{x+1/(2x)+O(x^{-3})} = \frac{2x^2+O(x^{-2})}{x(1+1/(2x^2)+O(x^{-4}))} = \frac{2x}{1+1/(2x^2)+O(x^{-4})} = 2x(1-1/(2x^2)+O(x^{-4})) = 2x - \frac{1}{x} + O(x^{-3})\).

For \(k \ge 3\), \(F_k(x,x,z) = \frac{2x^{k+1}+z^{k+1}}{x^2z} - (0^k + (x-z)^k + (z-x)^k)\).
If \(k\) is odd: \( (x-z)^k+(z-x)^k = (x-z)^k-(x-z)^k=0 \).
So \(F_k(x,x,z) = \frac{2x^{k+1}+z^{k+1}}{x^2z}\) for odd \(k\).
\(F_k(x,x,z) = \frac{2x^{k+1}+O(x^{-(k+1)})}{x+1/(2x)+O(x^{-3})} = \frac{2x^{k+1}(1+O(x^{-2k-2}))}{x(1+1/(2x^2)+O(x^{-4}))} = 2x^k(1-1/(2x^2)+O(x^{-4})) = 2x^k - x^{k-2} + O(x^{-k})\). (The \(O(x^{-4})\) dominates \(O(x^{-k})\) if \(k>4\)). More precise: \(2x^k - x^{k-2} + O(x^{-k_0})\) where \(k_0=\min(4,k)\).

If \(k\) is even: \( (x-z)^k+(z-x)^k = 2(x-z)^k \).
So \(F_k(x,x,z) = \frac{2x^{k+1}+z^{k+1}}{x^2z} - 2(x-z)^k\) for even \(k\).
The first term is \(2x^k-x^{k-2}+O(x^{-4})\).
The second term: \(2(x-z)^k = 2x^k(1-z/x)^k\).
\(z/x = 1/x^2+1/(2x^4)+O(x^{-6})\).
\(2x^k(1-k(z/x) + \frac{k(k-1)}{2}(z/x)^2 - \dots ) = 2x^k(1-k(1/x^2+1/(2x^4)) + \frac{k(k-1)}{2}(1/x^4) + O(x^{-6}))\).
\(= 2x^k - 2kx^{k-2} - kx^{k-4} + k(k-1)x^{k-4} + O(x^{k-6}) = 2x^k - 2kx^{k-2} + k(k-2)x^{k-4} + O(x^{k-6})\).
So, for even \(k \ge 4\):
\(F_k(x,x,z) = (2x^k-x^{k-2}) - (2x^k-2kx^{k-2}+k(k-2)x^{k-4}) + O(x^{-4})\) or \(O(x^{k-6})\).
\(F_k(x,x,z) = (2k-1)x^{k-2} - k(k-2)x^{k-4} + O(x^{- \min(4, k-6) })\). (The \(O(x^{-4})\) from first term needs to be specified as \(O(x^{k-4})\) or similar).
Specifically, \(F_4(x,x,z) \sim (2(4)-1)x^{4-2} - 4(4-2)x^{4-4} = 7x^2 - 8\).

Substitute these asymptotic forms into the equation \( (3c_2-c_0) + c_1 F_1(x,x,z) + \sum_{k=3}^n c_k F_k(x,x,z) = 0 \).
This equation must hold for all sufficiently large \(x\). The expression is a sum of terms with different powers of \(x\). For this sum to be zero, the coefficient of each power of \(x\) must be zero.
Let \(P(x) = \sum_{j=0}^N c_j x^j\), with \(c_N \ne 0\).
The sum is \( (3c_2-c_0) + c_1(2x - x^{-1} + \dots) + c_3(2x^3 - x + \dots) + c_4(7x^2 - 8 + \dots) + c_5(2x^5 - x^3 + \dots) + \dots = 0 \).
Suppose \(N \ge 3\).
If \(N\) is odd, say \(N=2m+1\) with \(m \ge 1\). The term with the highest power of \(x\) is \(c_{2m+1}(2x^{2m+1})\). For the sum to be zero, its coefficient must be zero, so \(2c_{2m+1}=0 \implies c_{2m+1}=0\). This contradicts \(c_N \ne 0\).
So there are no odd degree terms for \(N \ge 3\).
If \(N\) is even, say \(N=2m\) with \(m \ge 2\) (i.e. \(N \ge 4\)). The term with the highest power of \(x\) is \(c_{2m}F_{2m}(x,x,z) \sim c_{2m}((2(2m)-1)x^{2m-2})\). Its coefficient must be zero, so \((4m-1)c_{2m}=0\). Since \(4m-1 \ne 0\) for \(m \ge 2\), we must have \(c_{2m}=0\). This contradicts \(c_N \ne 0\).
So there are no even degree terms for \(N \ge 4\).
These arguments show that \(c_k=0\) for all \(k \ge 3\).
So the polynomial must be of degree at most 2: \(P(x)=c_2x^2+c_1x+c_0\).
The equation becomes \( (3c_2-c_0) + c_1 F_1(x,x,z) = 0 \).
Substituting the asymptotic expansion for \(F_1(x,x,z)\): \( (3c_2-c_0) + c_1(2x - 1/x + O(x^{-3})) = 0 \).
This must hold for all large \(x\).
The coefficient of \(x\) is \(2c_1\). So \(2c_1=0 \implies c_1=0\).
The equation becomes \( (3c_2-c_0) - c_1/x + O(x^{-3}) = 0 \). Since \(c_1=0\), this is \( (3c_2-c_0) + O(x^{-3}) = 0 \).
The constant term must be zero, so \(3c_2-c_0=0\).
Thus, the polynomial must satisfy \(c_k=0\) for \(k \ge 3\), \(c_1=0\), and \(c_0=3c_2\).
So \(P(x) = c_2x^2+3c_2 = c_2(x^2+3)\) for any constant \(c_2 \in \mathbb{R}\).

Let's verify this solution.
If \(P(x)=c(x^2+3)\) for some constant \(c\).
LHS = \( \sum_{\text{cyc}} \frac{c(x^2+3)}{yz} = c \left( \frac{x^3+y^3+z^3}{xyz} + 3\left(\frac{x+y+z}{xyz}\right) \right) \).
Using \(x+y+z=2xyz\), this becomes \(c \left( \frac{x^3+y^3+z^3}{xyz} + 3(2) \right) = c \left( \frac{x^3+y^3+z^3}{xyz} + 6 \right) \).
RHS = \( \sum_{\text{cyc}} P(x-y) = \sum_{\text{cyc}} c((x-y)^2+3) = c \left( (x-y)^2+(y-z)^2+(z-x)^2 + 9 \right) \).
So we need \( \frac{x^3+y^3+z^3}{xyz} + 6 = (x-y)^2+(y-z)^2+(z-x)^2+9 \).
This is equivalent to \( \frac{x^3+y^3+z^3}{xyz} - ((x-y)^2+(y-z)^2+(z-x)^2) = 3 \).
This is \(F_2(x,y,z)=3\), which we proved to be an identity for all \(x,y,z\) such that \(xyz \ne 0\). (The condition \(2xyz=x+y+z\) was used in simplifying \(F_2(x,y,z)\) in our derivation, but the identity \(3xyz=3xyz\) did not depend on it. Let's recheck.
\(F_2(x,y,z)xyz = x^3+y^3+z^3 - 2xyz(x^2+y^2+z^2-xy-yz-zx)\).
No, the condition was not used in simplifying \(F_2(x,y,z)xyz\) to \(x^3+y^3+z^3 - (x+y+z)(x^2+y^2+z^2-xy-yz-zx)\) IF we replace \(2xyz\) with \(x+y+z\).
The expression for \(F_2(x,y,z)\) is an identity regardless of the condition \(2xyz=x+y+z\).
The equation \(F_2(x,y,z)=3\) holds for any nonzero \(x,y,z\).
So \(P(x)=c(x^2+3)\) is indeed a solution for any constant \(c\). This includes the trivial solution \(P(x)=0\) when \(c=0\).

Final check of the argument steps:
1. Rewrite the original equation in terms of coefficients \(c_k\) and functions \(F_k(x,y,z)\).
2. Show \(F_2(x,y,z)=3\) identically. The equation becomes \( (3c_2-c_0) + c_1 F_1 + \sum_{k=3}^n c_k F_k = 0 \).
3. Restrict \(x,y,z\) to the curve \(y=x, z=2x/(2x^2-1)\).
4. Analyze the asymptotic behavior of \(F_k(x,x,z)\) as \(x \to \infty\).
5. Use these asymptotics to show that \(c_k=0\) for \(k \ge 3\) and \(c_1=0\), and \(3c_2-c_0=0\).
6. Conclude \(P(x)=c(x^2+3)\).
7. Verify the solution. The verification shows that \(P(x)=c(x^2+3)\) works provided \(F_2(x,y,z)=3\). The derivation of \(F_2(x,y,z)=3\) used the algebraic identity \(x^3+y^3+z^3 - (x+y+z)(x^2+y^2+z^2-xy-yz-zx) = 3xyz\), into which the condition \(x+y+z=2xyz\) was substituted for \(x+y+z\) to obtain \(x^3+y^3+z^3 - 2xyz(x^2+y^2+z^2-xy-yz-zx) = 3xyz\), which is precisely \(F_2(x,y,z)xyz = 3xyz\). This part is correct.

The set of solutions is all polynomials of the form \(P(x) = c(x^2+3)\) where \(c\) is any real constant.

The final answer is $\boxed{P(x) = c(x^2+3)}$ for any constant $c \in \mathbb{R}$

result.summary: The proof expands the unknown polynomial as P(x)=∑_{k=0}^n c_k x^k and rewrites the given functional equation as a linear combination ∑c_kF_k(x,y,z)=0 on the surface 2xyz=x+y+z, showing in particular F_2≡3. It then restricts to the one‐parameter family x=y, z=2x/(2x^2−1), uses asymptotic expansions of each F_k(x,x,z) as x→∞ to argue that c_k=0 for k≥3 and c_1=0, and deduces c_0=3c_2. Hence P(x)=c_2(x^2+3), which is checked to satisfy the equation.

issues.location: Case analysis eliminating c_N for even N
issues.text: “If N is even, say N=2m with m≥2. The term with the highest power of x is c_{2m}F_{2m}(x,x,z)∼c_{2m}((4m−1)x^{2m−2})”
issues.description: This step assumes F_{2m} produces the dominant x^{2m−2} term and ignores the possibility that F_{2m−1}(x,x,z)∼2x^{2m−1} from a nonzero c_{2m−1} could dominate, so one cannot isolate c_{2m} without first showing all lower‐index odd coefficients vanish.

issues.text: “For odd k: F_k(x,x,z)=2x^k−x^{k−2}+O(x^{−k}). For even k: F_k(x,x,z)=(2k−1)x^{k−2}−k(k−2)x^{k−4}+O(x^{k−6})”
issues.description: The error terms O(x^{−k}), O(x^{k−6}), etc., are introduced without derivation or consistent ordering, leaving it unclear that the claimed asymptotic expansions isolate distinct powers of x needed for coefficient comparison.

issues.location: Use of asymptotics on x=y slice
issues.text: “For this sum to be zero, the coefficient of each power of x must be zero.”
issues.description: The proof infers vanishing of all c_k by comparing asymptotic expansions on the one‐dimensional curve x=y, z=2x/(2x^2−1), but does not justify why a rational identity on this curve (rather than the full two‐dimensional surface) forces the original coefficients to vanish.

issues.location: Initial evaluation of the k=0 term on the RHS
issues.text: “For k=0, A^0+B^0+C^0=1+1+1=3 (assuming A,B,C≠0. If, say, x=y, then A=0, and A^0 is usually taken as 1 in polynomial sums. If x=y=z, then A=B=C=0…)”
issues.description: The discussion over 0^0 and edge cases here is unnecessary and overcomplicates a trivial fact ((x−y)^0=1 for any x,y), detracting from the clarity of the proof.
